reviewText: I ALWAYS LIKE RAY DANNON ON TV SHOWS. I NEVER KNEW HE WAS A BIG STAR AT ONE TIME.I LOVE OLD MOBSTER MOVIES SO I SAW HIM IN IT AND IT WAS WORTH IT. WARREN OATES ISHIS YOUNGER BROTHER IS GREAT. VERY WELL MADE AND ACTED. CAN'T BELIEVE THIS WASN'TEVER RUN ON LATE NIGHT MOVIES. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: Legs diamond based  on a true story good old action and drama  a dancer who became public enemy no 1made in the late 50s with a style of 30s  an 40s gangster films look for a young dyan cannon  who plays Dixie  lots of great shootout s an great print watch. Enjoy of a by gone era
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: This is an early 1960's gangster film starring Ray Danton as Legs Diamond. Danton is just about perfect in this role. The atmosphere and setting of Diamond's rise to success in the rackets is traced in a very convincing style. The film is in black and white, and this really helps the atmosphere of the movie. I rate this movie highly!
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: Since Little Caesar and Al Capone, gangster films by this time had a plot formula to follow: poor thief follows plan to take over the mob and replace the boss, climbs the ladder to the top only to meet an end of raining bullets. Ray Danton is well cast in the leading part but character actor Jesse White is hard to believe as a tough mafia leader and Elaine Stewart wears almost a disguise to play Arnold Rothstein's tough moll. Good performances help a cliched story, but it's been filmed before too often.
summary: Formula gangster pic with nothing new to offer
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: The movie is great with Ray Danton turning in what could be the role of his career.  Along with a new 'bit' actress Dyan Cannon as his 'moll' and B-movie stalwart Warren Oates, it's a very realistic 'gangster' film that doesn't glorify the lifestyle such as later 'gangster' films.  If you liked CAPONE with Ben Gazzara, you'll like this!But - like all Warner Bros. Archives releases, if you have a DVD/VCR combo unit, the disc formatting probably won't allow it to be played on your machine.  There are countless Warner Bros. Archives films I would love to own, but what's the good of owning them unless I can play them.  One of these days, I'll buy another player just for the Warner issues, but until then, make sure your player will accept the formatting on these discs.  As far as I can tell, Warner Bros. Archives is the only company that has this problem.  And why they 'did it' to us is beyond me.  Are you listening Warner Bros.??
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: I love older movies... Back and whites are my favorites! This was a good movie. A classic. I highly recommend. ;)
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: Talented director / screenwriter Budd Boetticher brought to life the violent story of infamous gangster, Jack "Legs" Diamond in this often overlooked, but high quality addition to the crime genre. The filming of this production in harsh black and white tones adds further realism to this gritty tale of illegal activities, shadowy ambushes and executions !Ray Danton is superb in the lead role as the treacherous and manipulative small time hoodlum who arrive's in New York and immediately sets about muscling in on everyone elses racket to build his own empire. A very young Warren Oates plays Danton's sickly brother, Eddie Diamond, in a low key yet interesting performance. Simon Oakland is the aggressive and determined Lt. Moody hounding Diamond every step of the way...and Robert Lowerey portrays Prohibition kingpin Arnold Rothstein.Boetticher's direction is fluid and crisp and he keeps this film noir gem tightly paced and holding your interest all the way through. Although Danton was never a major star, he simply shines in this film and his oily nature and good looks made him the perfect choice to play "the clay pidgeon" of the Prohibition era underworld.An engaging and stimulating film that will be enjoyed by fans of film noir underworld drama !FOOTNOTE: Diamond was known as "the clay pidgeon" of the underworld because of his repeated ability to survive assassination attempts...until he was betrayed and caught asleep one night and shot 6 times in the head ! And Diamond was not actually nicknamed "Legs" because of his dancing abilities, but rather for his habit on running out on his friends !
summary: Masterful story telling of Prohibition mobster !!
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: Danton is at his handsomest and ruthlessness as he makes his marks on the gangster underworld, using his good looks and charm to get the most from his girlfriends while plotting to become head of the Mob.  A wonderful Warner Bros. crime-er in B&W.;Dr. Ronald Schwartz, Manhattan
summary: Terrific gangster film and Ray Danton's best role as "Legs."
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS

reviewText: THE RISE AND FALL OF LEGS DIAMOND(1960) Directed by Bud Boetticher.Starring Ray Danton(as Jack "Legs" Diamond), Warren Oates (as Eddie Diamond), Jesse White, Frank DeKova, Gordon Jones, Simon Oakland, Dyan Cannon, Sid Melton and Robert Lowery as Arnold Rothstein.The macroscopically generally accurate but microscopically uninformed and frequently foolish biography of Jack "Legs" Diamond--the final burst of glory for the classic Irish gangster who almost but not quite grasped the brass ring of New York Crime before being murdered in 1931.Unfortunately the film was given to auteur director Boetticher which means, of course, that he would be more interested in making a movie about HIS personal issues than a reasonable film about the titular subject. Boetticher apparently had no functional knowledge about how Manhattan gangland in the 20s/early 30s operated, how a mob hit happened, the mechanics, the details etc etc. The set for Diamond's Hotsey Totsey Club is particularly ludicrous for anyone familiar with the real thing. He is more concerned with making a movie about a man who was incapable of love............which is fine as far as sociopath Diamond goes but the film needed much much more in the way of verisimilitude and accuracy......if even fictionalized than what passes for "sophistication" among the pseudo film intellectual. Apparently Boetticher thought that if he just tossed real names into the mix willy nilly irregardless of their place in crime history that would serve. It does not.A great pity really as Diamond's live is so filled with incident, violence, drama, great heights to plunging lows that his story told straight is the most Shakespearean of any of the lives of the gangsters of that time. He was practically a myth in his own lifetime among gangland as he was shot again and again throughout his career and survived hits that HAD killed his peers. He was also the only mobster who was forced to relocate to upstate New York and then, using there as a base, attempted to both reestablish himself in the city with a new mob made up of the last of the serious Irish gangsters as well as making alliances with Al Capone of Chicago but astonishingly the film chooses to skip all that. It DOES manage to have the most accurate dramatization of Diamond's death which has traditionally been misshapen beyond any recognition.In spite of the above, the film is not bad. Danton gives a good performance as Diamond------though he is too tall and muscular for the part nor is he terribly Irish. The rest of the cast do well with what they have. Simon Oakland is utterly wasted as a cop. The film is watchable and reasonably exciting. The weakness of the handling of the subject matter may not trouble the uninitiated.Pity it was not better though.Odd little bit of trivia. Robert Lowery was the second man to play Batman while Gordon Joneswas first man to play the Green Hornet.
Title: Rise & Fall of Legs Diamond VHS
